text: this is Adam eloch reporting from nan de
haar province Afghanistan a refugee
crisis is tearing apart lives at chomp
Tala camp near the Pakistan border under
this beige bale is a 35 year old mother
on the brink of desperation Varga has 11
children her 10 year old son suffers
from polio look at all these children
these small kids we don't have a roof
over our heads the weather is also very
cold here our savings have now run out
we have no hope other than God Varga and
her family are among three and a half
million Afghans who have voluntarily
returned from Pakistan since the Taliban
fell seven years ago the wealthy came
back first anxious to reclaim their land
but 2008 marks the return of the poorest
refugees almost three hundred thousand
of them most without land or family to
return to in November the United Nations
High Commissioner for Refugees Antonio
Guterres of Portugal visited chant Allah
these are the poorest of the poor the
most vulnerable of the vulnerable we
that live in normal houses that live in
countries that are spending billions of
dollars to rescue their financial
systems we need to understand that if we
are not able to rescue and to guarantee
them a dignified life then nothing makes
sense
international aid groups have provided
makeshift homes in water but the region
has four other camps like chomp de la
and there is not enough food medical
care and shelter to protect against the
winter chill life wasn't always so dire
for these refugees for decades in
Pakistan they lived in bustling camps
that were so large they seemed more like
towns but Pakistan closed two camps in
the past eighteen months
government officials said the camps were
sanctuaries for al-qaeda and the Taliban
the closures and Pakistan's crumbling
economy sent nearly 300,000 refugees
back home
there is little room for these returnees
in cities like Kabul where the
population has tripled in recent years
and more rural parts of the country
remain unsafe for return the result 60
percent of this year's returnees are
stuck in the inhospitable Eastern desert
chomp de la is a 40-minute drive from
civilization
three daily buses serve 4,000 families
and on this day the only passing
vehicles were not offering rides Abdul
Wahab a village elder had a large and
comfortable house in Pakistan now he
lives in a tent the government is
proceeding very slowly cheating us
stringing us along day by day will build
homes for you will give you tents and
plastic sheets but so far in eight
months nothing at an international
refugee conference in Kabul the Afghan
government has requested millions of
dollars from donor countries but the
funds won't arrive until the spring
seven years in to Afghanistan's
reconstruction the country still lacks
the money and the capacity to absorb its
own people the weather is getting cold
so the government should accelerate the
building of the homes as you know it's
impossible to live under these tents we
are in a country where we have an
administration that is still I would say
very inefficient in many aspects there
are corruption problems and the
government recognizes that mr. will have
the village elder has not given up
Yamuna this is the first day they came
here asking about the fate of our people
would assisted enough
over the years other camps have
gradually improved this camp is three
years old it has a school and a clinic
and signs of new progress but for the
poorest returnees a mild winter may be
their only hope
